column4:
Introduction

About this course
Our innovative programme offers a broad range of social science subjects. After completing your introductory studies you can either include in your final degree a range of subject areas or specialise in a specific âpathwayâ. Your degree will be made up from predetermined âcoreâ subjects and âoptionsâ that are chosen by you. Your choices are made from a possible six subject areas in social sciences. These are:

â¢
column10:
Sport

What you study
You will study eight modules per year. At stage one you will have core common modules from across the spectrum of social science pathways. This will enable you to experience the complete range of pathway opportunities whilst providing a sound foundation at the introductory stage of your degree. At stage two, three and four you will study âcoreâ modules in social sciences and option modules in subject areas of your choice. The remaining two options, at each stage, will be selected by you in conjunction with support from your year tutor.

You can achieve a broad coverage of topics by selecting modules combining the whole range of subject areas offered. Your selection of a specific pathway will provide you with specialisation in that particular area. This leads to the award of a BA in Social Science or BA (Hons) in Social Science. Alternatively, you can choose to major in a particular discipline.

You will develop your critical reasoning skills, your ability to collect and analyse quantitative and qualitative data, and your proficiency to communicate and debate with others. This degree has been designed with the notion of âemployabilityâ at its core. We are committed to facilitating your academic and personal development with a view to your ultimate employment. This is reflected both in the style of our teaching and the nature of our assessments.

How you learn
The course uses a variety of teaching methods, including lecturers, practical classes, seminars and tutorials. Most modules offer electronic supporting materials. In addition, you are expected to study and read independently. The number of contact hours per week varies from year to year, but typically you will be in class for approximately 12-15 hours per week and will work independently for approximately 20-25 hours per week.

How you are assessed
Assessments include essays, presentations, self-evaluation exercises, practical reports, multiple choice examinations, and written examinations. Modules vary from 100% coursework to 50% coursework and 50% examination.

column4:
Core Themes

A Good Foundation â Your first year studies ensure that you achieve a sound foundation as a basis for your future studies. In this first year you are introduced to the four main disciplines of the social sciences â sociology, economics, psychology and politics. You also acquire essential quantitative, IT, oral and written communication skills in this foundation year.

Sound Principles â In your second and third years you develop the four foundation subjects within the context of topical issues. In Sociology you consider various issues from the development of social identity to the nature of work in our society. In Economics you focus on assessing government policy decisions such as whether privatisation is the way forward for the railways. In Psychology you examine everyday memory, learning and development; and in Politics you discuss topics such as the role of statutory bodies and power in contemporary society.

Current Issues in the Social Sciences â You have a broad choice of study in third and fourth years. You can study particular subjects such as health, education or the environment, from a multidisciplinary point of view. Or you can choose unrelated subjects such as Child Language Development, Gender Studies, the Modern Corporation, Tourism and Economic Development.

Transferable Skills â You gain practical skills that you can apply in a wide variety of careers. You will be proficient in e-mail and word processing, able to build databases and make effective use of the Internet, and be familiar with the specialised software relevant to your subject choices. You will be able to analyse and evaluate detailed information quickly and competently, and know how to present the material facts in a direct and concise manner. You build upon your personal strengths such as self-motivation, assertiveness, and logical and reasoned thinking; and develop important workplace skills such as time management, team working and problem solving which are abilities highly regarded by employers.

Career Opportunities:

The programme is designed to prepare graduates for âpeople orientatedâ careers â jobs that require an understanding of how people think and act, and have high levels of interaction with others. It also prepares you for entry-level public sector posts. Graduates from our course have successfully entered fields such as social work, community education, teaching and lecturing, the Police service, care services, and public relations work.

column2: SQA HigherBBC at Higher Grade including English or another literate subject, eg. History, Geography, Modern Studies, Sociology or Psychology.
GCE A LevelCC at A Level including English or another literate subject, eg. History, Geography, Modern Studies, Sociology or Psychology.
Irish Leaving (H)BBCC at Honours Level including English or another literate subject at Honours Level.
Second Year EntryHNC in Social Sciences or equivalent.
Third Year EntryHND in Social Science or equivalent.
Minimum EntryFor further advice on minimum qualifications please use our Got a Question section.

MatureApplications from mature students are assessed on the same criteria used for school leavers e.g. SQA Highers or GCE A Levels, where relevant school leaving qualifications exist. For those without standard entry qualifications, consideration is given to experience gained as well as professional qualifications and other forms of learning that could provide evidence of ability to benefit from a particular course.

The successful completion of approved access courses (such as those offered by Dundee College in association with the universities of Abertay, Dundee and St Andrews) provides significant evidence of ability to benefit from study at Abertay.

For further advice please use our Got a Question section.

OverseasThe University makes offers of entry to courses based on qualifications offered worldwide.

All applicants are required to provide certified proof of competence in English Language. The University's minimum requirements are IELTS 6.0 (with no band lower than 5.0), TOEFL CBT 223, TOEFL 563, TOEFL IBT 85 or a suitable equivalent qualification.

column4:
Transferable skills

While studying on this course you will gain a number of practical skills that are useful in any field of business, such as how to use email, type reports, build a database and use the internet effectively as well as being introduced to specialised software relevant to your subject choices. You will also learn how to sift through vast quantities of detailed information quickly, and to present the important points in a concise and straightforward manner. As you progress through the degree course, you will gain other incidental skills which will prove invaluable in any future working environment. These may include:
1. Learning how to learn effectively
2. Self-motivation
3. Assertiveness
4. Time management
5. Meeting deadlines
6. Problem solving
7. Analysis, synthesis, discrimination and judgement
8. Logical and reasoned thinking.

Teamwork

Being able to work as a member of a team is an important quality in a University student. Working in a team situation allows you to utilise your own personal strengths and to build upon areas where you are lacking by learning from other people. It also allows you to gain experience in leading discussions and delegating responsibility, as well as learning to become an effective listener â an important leadership quality which can sometimes be overlooked. Making a positive contribution to a joint project allows you to develop team-working skills.
Working together on coursework often allows you to form close friendships in your social life as you learn to listen to and trust other peopleâs judgements.
